metadata.title: CASE 282/04: Investigation Report on Procurement Irregularities at Pristina Airport
metadata.primary_source: United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo

overview: This investigation report documents irregular procurement activities concerning the extension of the Cargo Apron at Pristina International Airport.

applicable_laws.excerpt: The law applicable in Kosovo shall be those promulgated by the Special Representative of the Secretary-General and the law in force on 22 March 1989.
Staff members shall uphold the highest standards of efficiency, competence, and integrity.
Competition among and participation in the procurement process shall be maximized.

methodology.description: Review of audit reports and procurement procedures.
interviews: Interviews with witnesses and persons potentially implicated in the allegations
documents_reviewed: Procurement records from Pristina International Airport
Tender documents including preliminary designs from the Evaluation Company

background.context: An audit report conducted by Chartered Accountants highlighted potential irregularities, initiating an investigation into procurement activities at Pristina International Airport.
entities_involved: Military Units of the Kosovo Force (KFOR)
timeline: 2003-02-28: Audit report issued on Pristina International Airport's financial statements.
2001;2003: Maintenance by PEAP in cooperation with KFOR
;2002-06-30: Administration by UNMIK's Civil Administration Pillar (Pillar II)
2004-04-01: Airport administration transferred to civilian jurisdiction under ICAO.
2002-07-01: Responsibility transferred from Pillar II to KTA and Pillar IV

investigation_details.subject: Irregularities in the procurement for the Cargo Apron extension at Pristina Airport

allegations.description: Tender specifications for the cargo apron did not comply with Article 23.3 of the UNMIK Finance Administrative Instruction 1999/2.
allegations.findings: Tender documents were based on summary documents without clear instructions on drawings and plans, corroborated by the evaluation report dated 2001-08-02.

allegations.description: Three members of the bid opening committee were also part of the technical evaluation committee.
allegations.findings: Conflict of role in violation of procurement regulations, supported by official confirmation by DOTI Official 2.

allegations.description: The contract was not submitted to the UNMIK Office of Legal Adviser for clearance.
allegations.findings: Confirmed by an interoffice memorandum dated 2001-09-24.

allegations.description: Vendor was allowed to certify its work per the contract requirements.
allegations.findings: Vendor self-produced test results, potentially breaching oversight requirements, as indicated by an interoffice memorandum and a letter dated 2001-06-27.

findings: Several procurement irregularities identified contravening established guidelines.
Evidence of role conflicts and oversight lapses in the procurement process.

actions: Strengthen oversight mechanisms for procurement processes.
Ensure separation of committees involved in procurement procedures.
Establish a mandatory review protocol by legal advisers for significant contracts.
Ensure all contracts are referred for legal advice before signing to reduce liability issues and avoid recurrences.
Ensure staff compliance with the UNMIK Public Procurement Regulation No 2004/3.
Ensure evaluations are conducted by a qualified independent entity.
Take appropriate action concerning DOTI Official 2.
